title-group.article-title: Solenoid actuator design and modeling with application in engine vibration isolators

author-notes.corresp: Siamak Arzanpour, Simon Fraser University, Surrey, BC, V3T 0A3, Canada Email: siamak_arzanpour@sfu.ca

abstract.p: This paper investigates the performance of a modified conventional solenoid valve as a low-cost controllable reciprocating force actuator. The applied modifications include adding a spring for plunger return mechanism, applying a bias current for pre-compression of the spring, and minor machining of the plunger rod. Potentially, this actuator can be employed in many applications, e.g. active noise and vibration control systems. A mathematical model of the actuator is given using the fundamental electromagnetic relationships. This model identifies the transfer function between the applied current and the output force. An experimental analysis in the frequency domain is conducted to obtain the current/force transfer function and validate the mathematical model. It is shown that in the stroke range of interest, the nonlinear analytical model of this actuator can be well estimated by a linear model. To investigate the performance of the actuator in a real application, this actuator is installed and tested in an active engine mount prototype. The analytical model of this engine mount is modified to include the actuator. The simulation result indicates that the stiffness and damping of this mount is tunable by controlling the input current to the actuator. The experimental results are also in close agreement with the simulations.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Solenoids are low cost stroke limited electromechanical actuators that are used in a wide variety of applications as on-off switches e.g. hydraulic and pneumatic valves in robot arms, packaging machines, active suspension dampers, etc; (Van Varseveld and Bone, 1997; McDonell and Bobrow, 1998; Lyshevski, 1999; Nguyen et al., 2007). In all of these applications, solenoids are preferred to other conventional actuators such as step motors, DC motors, and voice coils, mainly due to their low cost and simplicity.

This paper investigates using the solenoid actuators as a force generating mechanism for applications where the final cost plays an important role in design of the product e.g. vehicle engine mounts. Voice coil actuators have been used in the design of active mounts; voice coils have fast response time, create a high amount of force, and are compact. But despite their outstanding performance, compared to the original hydraulic engine mounts, the voice coil based active engine mounts are expensive and they are not affordable for low-end automotive applications. Voice coils can be replaced with the controllable force generating solenoid actuators and can be used for addressing an engine isolation problem as well as other similar problems. This actuator is scalable according to the force requirement and is inexpensive. However the main challenge is the nonlinear relation between the force and displacement in solenoids.

sec.title: 2. Actuator modeling
sec.p:
A solenoid valve consists of a coil, a metallic frame (C-frame), a moving plunger, (T-plunger) and a rebound spring. A lumped model of the valve is depicted in Figure 1. The relationship between the current in the coil and the magnetic field intensity is (1)Ni(t)=Hc(t)lc+Hg(t)lg(t)+Hp(t)lp, where N is the number of the coil turns, H(t) and l are the magnetic field intensity and length of the magnetic field and the subscripts c, p and g stands for C-frame, plunger, and air gap and i(t) is the electrical current in the coil (Taghizadeh et al., 2009). The magnetic force applied to the plunger, Fs, and the magnetizing inductance can be expressed as, (2)Fs=∂Wm∂xs, (3)L(xs,t)=Nφ(xs,t)i(t)=N2Rp+2Rg+Rc, Figure 1.
Lump model of a solenoid valve.

Where Wm = L(xs, t)i2(t)/2 and L(xs, t) is the magnetizing inductance and xs(t) is the plunger motion, φ is the magnetic flux and Rp, Rg, Rc are the magnetic reluctances of plunger, air-gap, and stationary core.

The mathematical descriptions of the reluctances are (4)Rp=lpμ0μpAe,Rg=lg2μ0Ae,Rc=lcμ0μcAe where μ0 is the permeability coefficient of the air, and μc and μp are the permeability coefficient of the core and the armature. Ae is the effective cross sectional area of the magnetic flux. In equation (4), lg/2 can also be expressed by lg/2 = x0 + xs(t), where x0 is the half of the air gap after applying the current i = cte. Combining equations (2), (3) and (4), the magnetic force becomes, (5)Fs(xs,t)=N2μ0μp2μc2Aeis2(t)(lpμc+2μpμc[x0+xs(t)]+lcμp)2
To simplify (5), new terms, α,β,γ are introduced as, (6)α=N2μ0μp2μc2Ae,β=lpμc+2μpμcx0+lcμp,γ=2μpμc.
As a result, the force applied by the magnetic field on the solenoid plunger is, (7)Fs(xs(t),i)=αi2(t)(β+γxs(t))2.

Coefficients α,β,γ are constant and depend on the permeability coefficients, effective magnetic flux areas, magnetic field lengths, and turn numbers; these coefficients can be evaluated experimentally. The force in (7) causes the plunger in Figure 1 to move inside the C-frame. If the applied current is constant the plunger will eventually settle at a new stable point.
The mechanical motion of the plunger for a time varying solenoid current input can be modelled by a mass-spring-damper model (equation (8)). (8)1ms[Fs(t)-bsx·s(t)-ksxs(t)]=x··s(t).

In equation (8), ms is the plunger mass, and ks and bs are the stiffness and damping of the rebound spring. Combining (7) and (8), the dynamics of the plunger motion will be: (9)-αi2(t)(β+γxs(t))2=mx··s(t)+bsx·s(t)+ksxs(t).

Regardless of the current direction, the solenoid coil always creates an attraction force on the plunger, towards the centre of the coil. That means, applying a harmonic current (with zero mean value), would create a harmonic output force with a frequency twice as the input frequency (Figure 2 (left)). This in fact, makes the solenoid inappropriate for actuation in a close loop control system. Figure 2.
Graphs on the left from top to bottom: oscillating current input to the solenoid and the force and position response (frequency of response is doubled). Graphs on the right from top to bottom: oscillating current plus constant bias input to the solenoid and the force and position response (frequency of response stayed the same).

To address this problem, a bias current can be initially applied to the coil. The solenoid force outputs in response to the input currents (with and without bias current) are illustrated in Figure 2. Applying a bias current (ib), to the coil creates an attraction force that will be balanced with the spring force and causes the plunger to settle at a new equilibrium point. This bias current should not bottom down the plunger; therefore, the bias current should not be large. By having a bias current in the system with a harmonically oscillating current (is), where 0≤is≤ib, the frequency of the output force will be equal to the input current frequency (Figure 2 (right)).

The solenoid actuator with a bias current, similar to other controllable actuators including voice coils, is able to create a reciprocating motion with an equal frequency to its input signal. Solenoid valves are available in a wide variety of sizes and forces. The common feature of these actuators is the limited motion stroke. Generating a motion at the same ranges of amplitudes as voice coils requires small variations in is. Moreover, in (6) the permeability factor, of ferrous material, μ, lies in the range 10−2–10−5(H·m−1) and xs is also in orders of 10−3(m), thus from (6), it is concluded that γ <<β. Therefore the effect of displacement in forcing function of equation (7) is neglected in applications with higher excitation frequency. Therefore the force function can be simplified into (10)Fs(i)=-αi2(t)β2=-α(ib+is(t))2β2.

Equation (10) is a parabola and it can be estimated by a line around the bias current operating point (equation (11) and Figure 3) (11)Fs(i)=-αi2(t)β2≈-2αibβ2(is+ib)+αib2β2=-2αibβ2is-αib2β2. Figure 3.
Linearization of the solenoid force function.

A simulation in the frequency domain is conducted to compare the linear and nonlinear equations of motion of the plunger. The frequency response of plunger acceleration (nonlinear force in equation (8)) in comparison to the response of the plunger to the linear forcing equation of (11) are depicted in Figure 4 for ib = 1 (A) and is = 0.4 (A). Working with a linear equation is easier than working with the nonlinear models; thus, it is easier to obtain a closed form solution for the linear systems with multiple components. The closed form solution is a useful design tool to design and fine-tune controllers. The frequency responses of the linearized and nonlinear model of solenoid (Figure 4) are in close agreement; therefore we can utilize the linear model of the solenoid. Figure 4.
Frequency response of the nonlinear solenoid model versus the linear approximate model of solenoid.

sec.title: 3. Actuator test and identification
sec.p: An experimental setup is developed to investigate the validity of the mathematical model that we developed. A solenoid (Magnetic Sensor Systems, Tubular low-profile clapper, S-16-261, AWG#21) is used in our experiments. To perform simulations, the parameters in equation (6) should be identified for this setting. A modification of the parameters in (6) will simplify the process of parameter identification. Using (11) and (8), the equation of motion of solenoid plunger can be written as: (12)-2αibβ2is-αib2β2=msx··s(t)+bsx·s(t)+ks(xs(t)+xc), where xc is the pre-compression length due to the constant bias current in the solenoid coil and -αib2β2=ksxc. Also, the term2αibβ2 in (12) is constant, and it can be represented by a bulk parameter Gs.
Therefore equation (12) can be stated as (13)-Gsis=msx··s(t)+bsx·s(t)+ksxs(t).

In equation (13) the stiffness, ks, is found by a static force/deflection test using dead-weights. To identify the Gs and the damping, bs, the acceleration response of the plunger in the frequency domain is used. In this test the acceleration response was preferred to a displacement response because it is easier to install an accelerometer on the solenoid plunger than a displacement sensor; a tiny accelerometer is glued to the plunger with inducing minimal disturbance to the test rather than installing a displacement sensor which needs a more delicate fixture and its contact with the plunger would have added undesirable disturbance forces to the response.
Equation (13) is transferred into the Laplace domain and expressed in terms of plunger acceleration as, (14)s2Xs(s)Is(s)=-s2Gsmss2+bss+ks.

It is expected from (14) that the plunger acceleration response has a 40 dB slope at low frequencies and its response becomes flat (constant) at the higher frequencies. The constant amplitude of the response at higher frequencies would be Gs/ms. Several frequency response tests were conducted in frequency range of 10–45 Hz. Based on our static measurements, the plunger mass is ms = 0.2 (Kg), and the stiffness is ks = 5900 (N·m−1). Dynamic test results are presented in Figure 5. Looking at Figure 5, the natural frequency is about 27.37 (Hz) (or 171.7 (rad·s−1)) which is consistent with the theoretical value obtained from (ωn=ks/ms). In higher frequency the amplitude of response is approximately 30 (dB) (DC gain) which is 20Log(Gs/ms); therefore the solenoid gain coefficient gain is Gs = 6.4 (N.A−1). Mathematical relation of damping is bs=2ζωnms and the magnitude of the response where the phase crosses −90(deg) is M-90 = 31.24 dB. From system theory we know that ζ=(DCgain)/(2×10M-9020)≈0.4. Therefore the damping ratio is approximately bs = 30 (N·m·s−1). Using the coefficient values, the equation of motion of solenoid plunger in Laplace domain is (s2Xs)/(Is)=(-6.4s2)/(0.2s2+30s+5900). Figure 5.
Frequency response of the acceleration of the plunger in response to the current input (solid lines) vs. the frequency response simulation of the identified linearized second order model (dashed line).

sec.title: 4.1. Engine mounts
sec.p: Engine mounts are used to isolate the passengers’ cabin from engine-generated noise and vibrations, and restrict the engine from large displacements. The hydraulic engine mount is a type of mount that is commonly used in vehicles. It is comprised of two fluid filled rubber chambers with different compliances, pumping chamber and compensation chamber. The pumping chamber has a thick rubber with a low compliance and the compensation chamber has a thin rubber with a high compliance. These two chambers are typically connected to each other through two passages, an inertia track and a decoupler. Refer to Golnaraghi and Jazar (2001) and Geisberger et al. (2002) for more information on hydraulic engine mounts.

sec.title: 4.2. Active engine mounts
sec.p: Active engine mounts exhibit higher levels of isolation performance due to their adjustable/controllable nature. Various actuators have been utilized in the design of active engine mounts such as on-off solenoid valves (Kim and Singh, 1995; Foumani et al., 2004), voice coil (Fursdon et al., 2000), piezoelectric actuator (Ushijima and Kumakawa, 1993), servo-hydraulic actuator (Hodgson, 1991), and electromagnetic inertia-mass (Shoureshi and Knureck, 1996; Hartwig et al., 2000). Among all active mount designs, the voice coil based design is the most often used option. All these previously mentioned active engine mounts use hydraulic engine mounts as their base design.

As a practical example for the application of the solenoid actuator, it is retrofitted inside a conventional hydraulic mount to investigate its performance in a real application as the actuator of an active engine mount. To fabricate the active mount prototype, the solenoid actuator (Figure 6(a)) is placed between the inertia track plate and the compensation chamber of a conventional hydraulic mount and sealed in a way that fluid does not leak into the coil (Figure 6(b)). Figure 6.
(a) The solenoid actuator, (b) Cross-section of the retrofitted solenoid actuator and the active mount prototype, (c) Schematics of the active mount and its parameters.

The base of the solenoid (coil and C-frame) is fixed indirectly to the chassis; therefore the electromagnetic reaction force is transmitted to the chassis. The equation of motion of the solenoid plunger is, (15)msx··s(t)+bsx·s(t)+ksxs(t)+Gsis+AsP1=0.

Where P1 is the dynamic pressure inside the pumping chamber and As is the surface of the solenoid plunger. The transmitted force to the chassis FT is, (16)FT=Krxe+Brx·e-ArP1+ksxs+bsx·s-Gsis, where Ar is the effective pumping area of the mount, Kr and Br are the rubber stiffness and damping respectively and xe is the displacement of engine mount with respect to the chassis.

After additional mathematical manipulation and Laplace transformation, the transmitted force can be written as (17)FT(s)=[Kr+Brs+Ar2ψ+(ks+bss)(AsArψ)-As2Ar2ψ2mss2+bss+(ks+As2ψ)]Xe +Gs[1+ArAsψ-(ks+bss)mss2+bss+(ks+As2ψ)]Is. where ψ=(IiC2s2+RiC2s+1)/(C2+C1[IiC2s2+RiC2s+1]); C1 and C2 are the pumping chamber and compliance chambers’ compliances, Ii and Ri are the inertia and resistance of inertia track. Details of the mathematical derivation of the previous formula are presented in Hosseini (2010).

To analyze the experimental and numerical results, the transfer function of dynamic stiffness was studied. This is a term widely used in the design of engine mounts for quantifying the property of the mounts. The dynamic stiffness is the ratio of the transmitted force to the relative displacement of the tip of the engine mount, KDyn = FT/Xe, and is often expressed in the frequency domain. The dynamic stiffness relation in our active engine mount prototype is, (18)FT(s)Xe=[Kr+Brs+Ar2ψ+(ks+bss)(AsArψ)-As2Ar2ψ2mss2+bss+(ks+As2ψ)] +Gs[1+ArAsψ-(ks+bss)mss2+bss+(ks+As2ψ)]IsXe

sec.title: 4.3. Dynamic stiffness tuning experiment
sec.p:
The experimental test-bed, depicted in Figure 7(b), is used to test the tuning of an active engine mount. The prototype is fixed between a rigid frame and an electromagnetic shaker. The motion of shaker emulates the engine vibration; the transmitted force and the relative displacement are recorded by a force sensor and a linear variable differential transformer (LVDT). The LVDT is used as a feedback to the solenoid coil to change the dynamic stiffness by generating reaction force on the chassis. The schematics of the test system is depicted in Figure 7(a). Figure 7.
(a) Schematics of engine mount prototype test, (b) Engine mount dynamic stiffness test-bed.

In equation (18), the terms in the first bracket are the contribution of the hydraulic engine mount (rubber, inertia track, and interaction of the fluid with the free solenoid plunger) to the dynamic stiffness; the terms in the second bracket are the contribution of the solenoid actuator to the dynamic stiffness. Is/Xe is the control block that is depicted in Figure 7(a). The dynamic stiffness of the active mount can be changed by tuning the control block.

The parameters of the engine mount prototype have been identified through tests and these parameters are Kr = 180 (N·mm−1), Br = 0.215 (N·s·mm−1), Ar = 3650 (mm2), As = 2900 (mm2), Ii = 3.4e-10 (Kg·m−4), Ri = 2.05e-8 (Kg·m−4·s−1), C1 = 2.25e5 (m4·s2·Kg−1), C2 = 2.03e7 (m4.s2·Kg−1), ks = 5.9 (N·mm−1), ms = 0.261 (Kg), bs = 0.03 (N·s·mm−1), Gs = -6.4 (N·A−1).

Suppose that we want to reduce the dynamic stiffness in the frequency range between 35 and 60 Hz which can be a real requirement for engine vibration isolation. To do so, a control block should be utilized to generate a desired force magnitude and it must have a phase shift around 180 degrees with respect to the response of passive components of the engine mount (hydraulic and rubber) so that the contribution of solenoid related dynamic stiffness gets subtracted from the rest of the dynamic stiffness terms and decrease the dynamic stiffness. Transfer function (19) is used as the control block Is/Xe, because it can create a contribution around 50 (N·mm−1) to the dynamic stiffness with 180 degree phase shift. That means that the dynamic stiffness will be reduced by 50 (N·mm−1) due to the phase shift (see Figure 8). Therefore this control function is a proper candidate for tuning of dynamic stiffness in this scenario. Note that this choice of tuning function is not unique and identification/design of the best transfer function is not the purpose of the paper. (19)IsXe=10(s+90)2s(s+240)(A·mm-1) Figure 8.
Contribution of actuator (active part), rubber and hydraulic (passive part), and the overall effect on the dynamic stiffness (Simulation).

The active engine mount is tested in frequencies (35–60 Hz) with emulated engine displacements of 0.1 (mm) peak-peak on the shaker setup which is shown in Figure 7 (b). Results of deploying this active transfer function in comparison to a passive mode hydraulic mount and the simulation of the equation (18) with the function (19) are depicted in Figure 9. Figure 9.
Dynamics stiffness of the hydraulic mount in passive mode (dashed line), dynamic stiffness of the active mount in a soft mode (solid line), and dynamic stiffness based on the derived model with the control function.

Figure 9 shows that the prototype is capable of changing the dynamic stiffness, the obtained mathematical model is predicting this change of dynamic stiffness with an acceptable precision, and the results of the lumped parameter model are in close agreement with the experimental results.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: The design and modeling of a low-cost force actuator are studied. Through analytical discussion and experiments, it was demonstrated that the nonlinear equation of solenoids can be linearized in specific applications. The application of this solenoid actuator in design of a low-cost active engine mounts is presented.
